title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: throughout the world for its linen and handkerchiefs; a little further onin Donegall Place is Lindsay's Ulster Arcade, and further on, on thesame side, is the Imperial Hotel, one of the finest hotels in the city;on the opposite side is the Royal Hotel, and Rodman's great art shopand picture gallery; near this is the Queen's Arcade, a large coveredpromenade, with fine shops on either side; and in Castle Place is theBank Buildings, once the Northern Bank, a grand emporium for allsorts of goods; facing which is Gibson's famous jewellery shop, andnext to it is Magill's art shop and picture gallery; facing DonegallPlace is the Ulster Club, where once stood Sloan's famous cabinetwarehouse, Page's hair-cutting establishment, and Ogston's pastry shop. At the corner of Royal Avenue, which was at one time a filthy street ofsmall butcher and other shops, but now one of the finest thoroughfaresin the city, is the Reform Club; and on the opposite side is the RoyalAvenue Hotel, a splendid establishment.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Postmaster has no letter for me; angry old fool reiterates 'None, I tell you!' and Duffy, who was there waiting and had a letter waiting, stayed in vain, and did not return till afternoon next day; would have had the Drogheda  official punished (or at least complained of), but I wouldn't. An angry old fool, misanthropic, not dishonest, pleaded I. Rolled into Duiiliu (lo Imperial Hotel) by railway. After sunset, wandered  far and wide about the broad pavements, listening to the wild melodies and cries of Dublin (on a Saturday night), went tired to bed, and, in spite of riotous sounds audible, slept well enough.

title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis
snippet: Our first walk in Ireland was from the Imperial Hotel to the Mardyke. Fifteen minutes brought us to the River Lee; and now, with the cityproper behind us, did we enjoy the lovely scene spread out to view.

title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis
snippet: A good hotel at Cork is the Imperial Hotel; the attendance prompt, thechamber linen fresh and clean, the viands well prepared.

title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis.
snippet: A good hotel at Cork is the Imperial Hotel; the attendance prompt, the chamber linen fresh and clean, the viandswell prepared.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: Half a dozen of the public buildings I saw were spacious and shabbybeyond all cockney belief. Adjoining the Imperial Hotel is a great,large, handsome, desolate reading-room, which was founded by a body ofCork merchants and tradesmen, and is the very picture of decay. NotPalmyra--not the Russell Institution in Great Coram Street--present moremelancholy appearances of faded greatness.

title: Abroad.
author: Coghill, J[ames] Henry. [from old catalog]
snippet: 18th. — We stopped at the Imperial Hotel, where we had fine accommodations. The morning was, much to our regret, too unpleasant to go out, and we had to leave without seeing much of the city.

title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis.
snippet: Our first walk in Ireland was from the Imperial Hotel tothe Mardyke. Fifteen minutes brought us to the River Lee;and now, with the city proper behind us, did avc enjoy thelovely scene spread out to vieAV.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: Half a dozen of the public buildings I saw were spacious and shabbybeyond all cockney belief. Adjoining the Imperial Hotel is a great,large, handsome, desolate reading-room, which was founded by a body ofCork merchants and tradesmen, and is the very picture of decay. NotPalmyra--not the Russell Institution in Great Coram Street--present moremelancholy appearances of faded greatness.

title: The British isles through an opera glass,
author: Taylor, Charles M.
snippet: church spires, rising above the other buildings, silently impress one with the Christian atmosphere of the community. Crossing the old Sligo Bridge, we drive through Knox Street, and at last halt before the Imperial Hotel. A rather attractive hall meets our eyes ; rooms are assigned us, and after a good supper, we retire for the night.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: In front of Carlisle Bridge, and not in the least crowded, tho in themidst of Sackville Street, stands Nelson upon a stone pillar. The postoffice is on his right hand (only it is cut off); and on his left,Gresham's and the Imperial Hotel. Of the latter let me say (fromsubsequent experience) that it is ornamented by a cook who could dress adinner by the side of M. Borel or M. Soyeld there were more such artistsin this ill-fated country! The street is exceedingly broad and handsome;the shops at the commencement, rich and spacious; but in Upper SackvilleStreet, which closes with the pretty building and gardens of theRotunda, the appearance of wealth begins to fade somewhat, and thehouses look as if they had seen better days.

title: Abroad.
author: Coghill, J[ames] Henry. [from old catalog]
snippet: m. We drove to the Imperial Hotel, where we dined ; left our trunks, and proceeded on the same afternoon to Portrush, We stopped at the " Antrim Arms" Hotel, a very fine house, but so crowded that we had to occupy very poor rooms. We noticed a marked difference between the country we passed over to-day and that between Killarney and Dublin.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: To T. Carlyle, Imperial Hotel, Dublin, Ireland.
